content:
Per poter inquadrare il problema prova a fornire queste informazioni:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)
creator: @next

content: Unfortunately, there is no easy solution. Thunderbird's junk filter can help, but it requires active and frequent training. More info at https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-and-junk-spam-messages I also suggest checking to see if your email provider offers a junk filter online, such as Spamassasin. I, personally, use Mailwasher and have found it addresses the issue quite well (it's free for one account and this is NOT an official endorsement.)

content: Primary password isn't something you can recover. And if I remember correctly it warns you when you create it. The only thing you can do is reset (remove) the primary password and start over with your passwords. Please see https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/protect-your-thunderbird-passwords-primary-password
creator: wsmwk

content:
I do not know OSX, but here are the basic steps:

Here is the link for moving a profile in Windows when installed in default location: 

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  8. start thunderbird and all should be there
creator: davidsk

creator: sfhowes

content:
No, you can't point a filter from one profile to a folder in a different profile. Profiles are meant to be separate, so there are no affordances for users to do something that most users should not do.

You can however start Thunderbird with profile A (let's call that instance A) nd point the messages store for folder C to a location in profile B (let's call that instance B). Then, while running Thunderbird with profile A you can have a folder that sends messages to folder C.

But you must not be running Thunderbird against instance A and B at the same time.
creator: wsmwk

content:
If you've disabled TB's built-in junk controls, any other junk or spam filtering is being done by the mail service, independent of TB.

See https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1404881
